docs.title: What is Codekub?
docs.text:
Codekub is a beginner-focused Linux setup script that installs and configures everything a Computer Science / IT student needs to start coding from day one.

Instead of spending weeks figuring out:

  • which tools to install
  • how to configure them
  • why things break

Codekub gives you a ready-to-learn development environment, while also teaching you what each tool does and why it exists.

docs.title: How Codekub Works
docs.text:
Codekub is installed using a single command:

wget -qO- https://omakub.org/install | bash

⚠️ Note: The idea of using a single install script is inspired by Omakub, but Codekub is a completely different project with a different goal and audience.

docs.title: Omakub
docs.text:
• Made for experienced developers
  • Opinionated, fast, production-ready
  • Assumes you already understand Linux, terminals, and tools
  • Focuses on getting work done quickly

docs.title: Codekub
docs.text:
• Made for beginners and students
  • Learning-first, explanation-driven setup
  • Beginner-friendly defaults
  • Focuses on understanding tools, not hiding them

👉 Omakub installs tools. 👉 Codekub teaches tools.

docs.title: Who Is Codekub For?
docs.text:
🎓 CSE / IT students 🧑‍💻 Programming beginners 🚀 Anyone learning development tools from scratch

If you are:

  • new to Linux
  • confused by terminals
  • unsure why developers use tools like Git, Docker, or Neovim

Codekub is for you.

docs.title: What Codekub Installs
docs.text: Codekub provides a modern, real-world developer environment, carefully chosen for learning.

docs.title: Programming Languages & Compilers
docs.text:
• C / C++
  • Java
  • Python
  • Rust
  • Node.js

docs.title: Developer Tools
docs.text:
• Git
  • Docker
  • VS Code
  • Neovim
  • Tmux
  • Modern CLI utilities

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text:
• Preconfigured dotfiles
  • Clean GNOME customizations
  • Learning-friendly terminal setup
  • Sensible defaults (no unnecessary complexity)

Everything works out of the box, but nothing is hidden.

docs.title: What Makes Codekub Different
docs.text:
Codekub emphasizes:

✅ Clear explanations of tools and configurations ✅ Beginner-oriented defaults ✅ Step-by-step guides ✅ Practical learning over “magic scripts” ✅ Modern development workflows ✅ A clean, beautiful Linux experience without overwhelm

Instead of just installing tools, Codekub helps you understand them.

docs.title: Learning-First Philosophy
docs.text:
Most setups assume:

“You’ll figure it out later.”

Codekub assumes:

“You are learning — let’s explain everything.”

You learn:

  • what each tool does
  • why developers use it
  • how it fits into real projects

This makes Codekub ideal for:

  • academic labs (personal learning)
  • self-study
  • first-time Linux users
  • long-term skill building

docs.title: License & Usage Notice
docs.text:
✅ Free for students and personal learning ❌ Not allowed for commercial use ❌ Not allowed for college labs or institutional deployment

Codekub is built to help individual learners, not organizations.

docs.title: Project Background (Transparency Note)
docs.text:
This project started before I knew about Omakub. Later, the script-based installer idea was inspired by Omakub.

However:

  • Codekub has a different mission
  • Codekub targets beginners
  • Codekub focuses on learning, not speed

docs.title: Hotkeys
docs.text: Here’s a beginner-friendly and structured guide for Linux hotkeys, Neovim shortcuts, and quick emoji triggers, written in Codekub style.

docs.title: Linux Hotkeys: Mastering Your Keyboard
docs.text: Linux is keyboard-first, and learning hotkeys is the fastest way to boost productivity.

docs.title: 1. Navigating the System
docs.text:
Hotkey Function Super + Space Launch app by typing Super + A See all apps Super + W Close app Super + 1/2/3/4 Jump to workspace Shift + Super + 1/2/3/4 Move app to workspace Alt + 1/2/3/... Jump to dock app Ctrl + 1/2/3/... Jump to browser tab

💡 Tip: Think of Super as your “Linux command key”.

docs.title: 2. Tiling Windows
docs.text:
Hotkey Function F11 Full screen Shift + F11 Full screen with title bar Super + Left/Right Fill left/right half Super + Up Fill full screen Super + T Open tiling overlay Super + Shift + T Open tiling settings Super + T W S Fill center vertical Super + T Q A Fill left vertical Super + T E D Fill right vertical Super + T Q Q Fill upper left Super + T A A Fill lower left

💡 Tip: Combine with Super + arrow keys for fast window organization.

docs.title: 3. Application Windows
docs.text: Hotkey Function Super + W Close window/application Alt + Space Reveal options (Undecorate removes title bar)

docs.title: 4. Terminal (Zellij)
docs.text:
Hotkey Function Ctrl + G P R New vertical pane Ctrl + G P D New horizontal pane Alt + Arrow Navigate panes/tabs Alt + = / Alt + - Expand / Shrink pane Ctrl + G T N New tab Ctrl + G T R Rename tab Ctrl + G O D Suspend session Ctrl + G O W Resume session Ctrl + G S E Edit scroll history Ctrl + R Reveal command history

💡 Tip: Zellij turns your terminal into a multi-pane powerhouse.

docs.title: 5. File Manager
docs.text: Hotkey Function Ctrl + L Go to path Space Preview file Backspace Go back one folder

docs.title: 6. Apple Display Brightness (Optional: ASDControl)
docs.text: Hotkey Function Ctrl + F1 Decrease brightness Ctrl + F2 Increase brightness Ctrl + Shift + F2 Max brightness

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text: Hotkey Function Space Show command options Space Space Open file (fuzzy search) Space E Toggle sidebar Space G G Git controls Space S G Search file content Ctrl + W W Switch between sidebar & editor Ctrl + Left/Right Resize sidebar Shift + H / L Move left/right file tab Space B D Close file tab

docs.title: Sidebar Operations
docs.text:
Hotkey Function A Add new file in parent dir Shift + A Add subdir D Delete file/dir M Move file/dir R Rename file/dir ? Show help

💡 Tip: LazyVim turns Neovim into a modern IDE with minimal effort.

docs.title: 8. Quick Emojis

Hotkey Emoji Clue CapsLock M S 😄 smile CapsLock M C 😂 cry CapsLock M L 😍 love CapsLock M V ✌️ victory CapsLock M H ❤️ heart CapsLock M Y 👍 yes CapsLock M N 👎 no CapsLock M F 🖕 fuck CapsLock M W 🤞 wish CapsLock M R 🤘 rock CapsLock M K 😘 kiss CapsLock M E 🙄 eyeroll CapsLock M P 🙏 pray CapsLock M D 🤤 drool CapsLock M M 💰 money CapsLock M X 🎉 celebrate CapsLock M 1 💯 100% CapsLock M T 🥂 toast CapsLock M O 👌 ok CapsLock M G 👋 greeting CapsLock M A 💪 arm CapsLock M B 🤯 blowing mind

💡 Tip: These shortcuts speed up communication in chat or coding environments.

docs.title: ✅ Quick Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Super key = your master key for GNOME navigation and tiling
  2. Zellij + terminal shortcuts = multi-pane coding superpower
  3. LazyVim shortcuts = modern IDE experience in Neovim
  4. Quick Emojis = express yourself fast without leaving keyboard

docs.title: Tiling
docs.text: Here’s a beginner-friendly explanation of window tiling in GNOME and Tactile, written in Codekub style, keeping it clear, concise, and actionable:

docs.title: Window Management & Tiling in GNOME
docs.text: Managing multiple apps efficiently is key for productivity, especially when coding or working on projects.

docs.title: Basic Two-Way Tiling (For Small Screens)
docs.text:
GNOME comes with built-in simple tiling:

  • Super + Left Arrow → Snap active window to the left half
  • Super + Right Arrow → Snap active window to the right half
  • Super + Up Arrow → Maximize the window (fills screen, top panel visible)

💡 Example: Place your browser on the left and terminal on the right. This is ideal for laptops with smaller screens.

Tip: It’s a good alternative to one-app-per-workspace setups.

docs.title: Advanced Tiling with Tactile (For Big Screens)
docs.text:
If you have a larger monitor, you can use Tactile, which splits the screen into 6 regions by default:

  • Center: Two large slots
  • Wings: Two slots on each side (smaller)

Key commands:

  • Super + T → Activate Tactile grid
  • Super + T + [slot letters] → Assign window to specific slots

💡 Examples:

  1. Assign a terminal to the E slot: Super + T E
  2. Expand it to fill both center slots: Super + T W S
  3. Combine multiple apps: two terminals in wings, browser in center

Tactile lets you fit multiple windows efficiently without manually resizing each one.

docs.title: Moving Windows Manually
docs.text:
Sometimes manual adjustment is needed:

  • With title bar: Click and drag the title bar
  • Without title bar (e.g., Alacritty terminal): Hold Super, click anywhere inside the window, and drag

💡 Tip: This works even for windows with title bars, giving you flexibility when needed.

docs.title: Quick Summary
docs.text: Feature Shortcut / Action Use Case Snap left/right Super + Left/Right Two-way tiling on small screens Maximize Super + Up Fill screen without hiding top panel Tactile grid Super + T Advanced multi-window tiling Move manually Super + click & drag Adjust windows with or without title bars

docs.title: Why This Matters for Developers
docs.text:
• Keep terminal, IDE, browser, and documentation visible
  • Switch between coding, testing, and debugging quickly
  • Reduces time wasted resizing windows
  • Makes multi-tasking natural

If you want, I can next create a visual “GNOME + Tactile tiling cheat sheet” with keyboard shortcuts and examples that beginners can print or keep on screen while working.

Do you want me to do that?

docs.title: Clipboard (Copy & Paste in Linux)
docs.text:
Copy and paste may feel surprisingly confusing at first on Linux, especially if you are coming from macOS or Windows, where the same shortcuts work everywhere.

On Linux, the confusion mainly comes from the terminal.

docs.title: Why Ctrl + C / Ctrl + V Don’t Work in the Terminal
docs.text:
In graphical apps (like browsers or editors), copy and paste work normally:

  • Copy: Ctrl + C
  • Paste: Ctrl + V

But in the terminal, these keys already have special meanings:

  • Ctrl + C → Stops (kills) a running command
  • Ctrl + V → Inserts a control character

So Linux uses different shortcuts inside the terminal.

docs.title: Terminal Copy & Paste Shortcuts
docs.text:
Inside the terminal, use:

  • Copy: Shift + Ctrl + C
  • Paste: Shift + Ctrl + V

If you accidentally press Ctrl + V, you may see a strange character appear. Just delete it and use the correct paste shortcut.

💡 Tip: This takes some time to build muscle memory — everyone struggles with it at first.

docs.title: Copying Text with the Mouse (Terminal & Zellij)
docs.text:
When using terminal tools like Zellij, copying with the mouse has extra rules:

  1. Hold Shift
  2. Select text with the mouse
  3. Press Shift + Ctrl + C to copy

Without holding Shift, your mouse selection may not work correctly.

⚠️ Note: Mouse selection can feel a bit finicky at first, especially with exact positioning — this is normal. You’ll get used to it quickly.

docs.title: Clipboard Extension (Visual Clipboard History)
docs.text:
Codekub also includes a clipboard extension in the bottom bar.

This allows you to:

  • See everything you’ve copied recently
  • Quickly reuse previous text
  • Avoid losing important copied commands or code

It’s extremely useful when:

  • Copying multiple commands
  • Switching between documentation and terminal
  • Learning Linux and experimenting

Think of it as a clipboard history manager that makes learning much easier.

docs.title: Programming Languages (How We Talk to Computers)
docs.text:
Computers don’t understand human language. They only understand instructions.

A programming language is a way for humans to write instructions that computers can understand and execute.

Think of a programming language as:

A bridge between human thinking and machine execution.

docs.title: Why There Are Many Programming Languages
docs.text:
Different problems need different tools:

  • Some languages are fast
  • Some are easy to learn
  • Some control hardware
  • Some build websites
  • Some power large systems

That’s why engineers learn more than one language.

docs.title: Node.js (JavaScript on the Server)
docs.text:
Node.js lets you run JavaScript outside the browser.

Used for:

  • backend servers
  • APIs
  • real-time apps
  • tools and automation

Why engineers use it:

  • same language for frontend and backend
  • fast and event-driven
  • huge ecosystem

Mental model:

JavaScript for servers.

docs.title: Java (Write Once, Run Anywhere)
docs.text:
Java is a strongly-typed, object-oriented language.

Used for:

  • enterprise software
  • Android apps
  • large backend systems

Why engineers use it:

  • very stable
  • huge industry usage
  • excellent tooling

Mental model:

Safe, structured language for big systems.

docs.title: PHP (Web-Focused Language)
docs.text:
PHP is a server-side language designed for the web.

Used for:

  • websites
  • content management systems
  • backend logic

Why engineers use it:

  • easy to start
  • powers many websites
  • great for web development

Mental model:

Language made for websites.

docs.title: C (Close to the Machine)
docs.text:
C is a low-level programming language.

Used for:

  • operating systems
  • embedded systems
  • compilers

Why engineers use it:

  • very fast
  • full control over memory
  • teaches how computers really work

Mental model:

Talk almost directly to hardware.

docs.title: C++ (C with Power and Abstractions)
docs.text:
C++ builds on C with more features.

Used for:

  • game engines
  • system software
  • high-performance applications

Why engineers use it:

  • extremely powerful
  • high performance
  • used in complex systems

Mental model:

C + advanced programming features.

docs.title: Python (Readable and Beginner-Friendly)
docs.text:
Python focuses on simplicity and readability.

Used for:

  • scripting
  • data science
  • AI and machine learning
  • automation
  • web development

Why engineers use it:

  • easy to learn
  • very expressive
  • huge library support

Mental model:

Write less, do more.

docs.title: Important Beginner Truth
docs.text:
No single language is “the best”.

Good engineers:

  • learn concepts
  • switch languages when needed
  • choose the right tool for the problem

Languages change — thinking skills don’t.

docs.title: RSS Reader (Why Engineers Use It)
docs.text:
As a developer, learning never stops. New tools, bugs, security issues, frameworks, and best practices appear every day.

Engineers use RSS readers to stay updated without distractions.

docs.title: What Is RSS?
docs.text:
RSS (Really Simple Syndication) is a way to subscribe to websites and receive new content automatically.

Instead of:

  • visiting 10–20 blogs every day
  • scrolling through social media
  • relying on algorithms

You get new posts delivered directly to you in one place.

docs.title: Why Engineers Prefer RSS Readers
docs.text: Engineers use RSS readers because they are:

docs.title: 🔕 Distraction-Free
docs.text:
• No ads
  • No notifications
  • No algorithm manipulation

You read only what you choose.

docs.title: 🧠 High-Signal Information
docs.text:
Engineers follow:

  • Programming blogs
  • Linux news
  • Security advisories
  • Open-source project updates

RSS gives pure content, not noise.

docs.title: ⚡ Time Efficient
docs.text:
• Open one app
  • See all updates
  • Read what matters
  • Ignore the rest

Perfect for busy students and professionals.

docs.title: 📚 Learning-Oriented
docs.text:
RSS helps you build a habit of reading technical content, which is a core engineering skill.

Many senior engineers still rely on RSS daily.

docs.title: Engineer Blogs Commonly Followed via RSS
docs.text:
Examples of content engineers subscribe to:

  • Linux & system blogs
  • Programming language blogs (Python, Rust, Java, C++)
  • Security blogs
  • Open-source project updates
  • Engineering blogs from companies

RSS lets you own your learning feed.

docs.title: Liferea – The RSS Reader Used in Codekub
docs.text:
Liferea (Linux Feed Reader) is a simple, fast, and lightweight RSS reader.

It is included in Codekub to encourage healthy learning habits.

docs.title: Why Liferea?
docs.text:
Liferea is:

  • Easy for beginners
  • Very lightweight
  • No account required
  • Works fully offline once feeds are loaded
  • Native Linux application

Perfect for students new to RSS.

docs.title: What You Can Do with Liferea
docs.text:
• Subscribe to blog feeds
  • Read articles in a clean layout
  • Mark articles as read
  • Organize feeds into folders
  • Open links in your browser if needed

docs.title: How Engineers Actually Use RSS (Real Workflow)
docs.text:
A common habit:

  1. Open Liferea once or twice a day
  2. Scan headlines
  3. Read 1–2 useful articles
  4. Ignore the rest without guilt

No doom-scrolling. No pressure.

docs.title: Obsidian (How Software Engineers Think With Notes)
docs.text:
As a software engineer, learning is not just about writing code — it’s about thinking clearly, remembering concepts, and connecting ideas over time.

That’s why many engineers use Obsidian.

docs.title: What Is Obsidian?
docs.text:
Obsidian is a markdown-based note-taking app designed for thinking, learning, and knowledge building.

Unlike normal note apps:

  • Your notes are plain text files
  • Stored locally on your computer
  • Fully under your control

No cloud lock-in. No hidden formats.

docs.title: 🧠 Engineers Think in Connections, Not Pages
docs.text:
Engineering knowledge is connected:

  • Data Structures → Algorithms → Optimization
  • Linux → Processes → Containers → Docker
  • Git → Branching → CI/CD

Obsidian lets you link notes together, just like a graph of ideas.

This mirrors how engineers actually think.

docs.title: ✍️ Markdown Fits Engineers Perfectly
docs.text:
Obsidian uses Markdown, which engineers already use for:

  • README files
  • Documentation
  • GitHub projects
  • Technical writing

You write notes using simple text like:

# Git Basics
- git init
- git commit
- git push

No formatting distractions.

docs.title: 🗂️ Your Knowledge Grows With You
docs.text:
Engineers don’t “finish learning” a topic.

With Obsidian:

  • You start with simple notes
  • Add details over time
  • Link related concepts later
  • Revisit and improve understanding

Your notes become a personal knowledge base.

docs.title: 🔒 Local-First & Offline
docs.text:
Engineers value control and privacy.

Obsidian:

  • Stores notes locally
  • Works fully offline
  • Uses normal folders and files

You can back it up with Git, cloud sync, or USB — your choice.

docs.title: 📈 Used by Real Engineers (Not Just Students)
docs.text:
Obsidian is used by:

  • Software engineers
  • Security researchers
  • System architects
  • Researchers and writers

Many engineers treat Obsidian as their second brain.

docs.title: How Engineers Actually Use Obsidian
docs.text:
Typical real-world usage:

  • Notes on programming languages
  • Linux command explanations
  • Debugging notes
  • Project architecture ideas
  • Interview preparation
  • Personal learning journal

It’s not about pretty notes — it’s about useful notes.

docs.title: Readest (Read Anywhere, Without Distractions)
docs.text:
Engineers read a lot:

  • documentation
  • blogs
  • tutorials
  • long technical articles

But reading on the web is often distracting.

That’s why many engineers use Readest.

docs.title: What Is Readest?
docs.text:
Readest is a read-it-later and distraction-free reading app.

It allows you to:

  • save articles to read later
  • remove ads and clutter
  • read in a clean, book-like view
  • sync your reading across devices

Think of Readest as a personal reading library.

docs.title: 🧘 Focused Reading
docs.text:
Web pages are full of:

  • ads
  • popups
  • banners
  • autoplay videos

Readest strips all of that away and shows only the content.

Engineers prefer focus over noise.

docs.title: 📚 Read When You’re Ready
docs.text:
When learning:

  • you find good articles at random times
  • you don’t always have time to read immediately

Readest lets you:

  • save links now
  • read later when your mind is fresh

docs.title: 🧠 Better Understanding
docs.text:
Clean text = better concentration.

Engineers often read:

  • complex explanations
  • long technical posts

Readest makes long reading less tiring.

docs.title: 🌙 Comfortable Reading Experience
docs.text:
Readest supports:

  • dark mode
  • font size adjustment
  • clean typography

This reduces eye strain during long study sessions.

docs.title: Cross-Sync: Mobile, Laptop, Everywhere
docs.text:
One of the biggest reasons engineers use Readest is cross-sync.

You can:

  • save an article on your laptop
  • read it later on your mobile
  • continue where you left off

Your reading progress stays synced.

This is perfect for:

  • commuting
  • breaks
  • late-night reading

docs.title: Typical Engineer Workflow with Readest
docs.text:
1. Find a good article while coding
  2. Save it to Readest
  3. Read it later on phone or laptop
  4. Come back with better understanding

No pressure. No distraction.

docs.title: Ulauncher (Become Fast Without Thinking)
docs.text:
Top engineers don’t waste time clicking around menus. They launch things instantly.

That’s where Ulauncher comes in.

docs.title: What Is Ulauncher?
docs.text:
Ulauncher is a keyboard-based application launcher.

Instead of:

  • opening menus
  • searching with a mouse

You press one shortcut, type a few letters, and hit Enter.

docs.title: ⚡ Speed
docs.text:
• Open apps instantly
  • Launch files without browsing folders
  • Run commands quickly

Small time savings add up.

docs.title: 🧠 Less Context Switching
docs.text:
Using the mouse breaks focus.

Ulauncher lets you:

  • stay on the keyboard
  • keep your mind in “coding mode”

This is a key habit of top engineers.

docs.title: 🔎 One Tool, Many Uses
docs.text:
With Ulauncher, you can:

  • launch apps
  • search files
  • calculate math
  • run terminal commands
  • search the web

All from one box.

docs.title: Basic Usage (All You Need to Know)
docs.text:
1. Press the Ulauncher shortcut (usually Alt + Space)
  2. Start typing what you want
  3. Press Enter

That’s it.

You don’t need to memorize commands.

docs.title: Why Beginners Should Learn It Early
docs.text:
Beginners often:

  • rely heavily on the mouse
  • lose focus switching windows

Learning Ulauncher early helps you:

  • build keyboard-first habits
  • move faster naturally
  • think like experienced engineers

docs.title: VirtualBox (Run One Computer Inside Another)
docs.text:
Sometimes you want to:

  • try a new operating system
  • experiment without risk
  • learn safely without breaking your main system

VirtualBox lets you do this.

docs.title: What Is VirtualBox?
docs.text:
VirtualBox is a virtualization software.

It allows you to run a virtual computer (virtual machine) inside your real computer.

You can install:

  • Linux
  • Windows
  • other operating systems

inside a window, like an app.

docs.title: 🧪 Safe Experimentation
docs.text:
You can:

  • break things
  • try risky commands
  • install new systems

Without harming your main OS.

docs.title: 📚 Perfect for Learning
docs.text:
Students use VirtualBox to:

  • learn Linux
  • test servers
  • practice networking
  • run different OS versions

No fear, no damage.

docs.title: 🔁 Multiple Systems, One Machine
docs.text:
Run:

  • Linux + Windows
  • multiple Linux distros
  • old OS versions

All on the same laptop.

docs.title: 🏗️ Used in Education & Industry
docs.text:
VirtualBox is widely used in:

  • colleges
  • labs
  • training environments

It’s a standard learning tool.

docs.title: Docker (Run Anything, Anywhere)
docs.text:
One of the biggest problems beginners face is:

“It works on my machine, but not on yours.”

Docker solves this.

docs.title: What Is Docker?
docs.text:
Docker is a tool that lets you run applications inside containers.

A container includes:

  • the app
  • its libraries
  • its dependencies
  • its environment

Everything needed to run the app — bundled together.

docs.title: 🧩 No Setup Pain
docs.text:
Instead of installing:

  • databases
  • runtimes
  • libraries

You just run a container.

One command. Done.

docs.title: 🔁 Same Everywhere
docs.text:
Docker runs the same on:

  • your laptop
  • your friend’s laptop
  • college lab machines
  • servers

No “works on my system” problems.

docs.title: ⚡ Fast & Lightweight
docs.text:
Containers:

  • start instantly
  • use fewer resources than virtual machines

Perfect for development.

docs.title: 🏗️ Industry Standard
docs.text:
Docker is used by:

  • startups
  • big tech companies
  • cloud platforms

Learning Docker early is a career advantage.

docs.title: How Beginners Should Think About Docker
docs.text:
Think of Docker as:

“A clean, disposable computer for my app.”

If something breaks:

  • delete the container
  • start again

No fear of breaking your system.

docs.title: One Simple Example
docs.text:
Run a database without installing it:

docker run postgres

That’s it.

No manual setup. No config files.

docs.title: How Top Engineers Use Docker
docs.text:
• Local development
  • Testing environments
  • CI/CD pipelines
  • Microservices
  • Cloud deployment

Same tool. Bigger scale.

docs.title: GitHub CLI (Work With GitHub Without Leaving the Terminal)
docs.text:
Good engineers don’t constantly switch between browser ↔ terminal ↔ browser.

They use GitHub CLI.

docs.title: What Is GitHub CLI?
docs.text:
GitHub CLI (gh) lets you use GitHub directly from the terminal.

You can:

  • create repositories
  • manage pull requests
  • review issues
  • authenticate securely

All without opening a browser.

docs.title: ⚡ Faster Workflow
docs.text:
No tab switching.

You stay in the terminal and:

  • push code
  • create PRs
  • check CI status

Flow stays unbroken.

docs.title: 🧠 Less Cognitive Load
docs.text:
The terminal is where engineers already work.

GitHub CLI keeps:

  • code
  • version control
  • collaboration

in one place.

docs.title: 🔐 Secure & Professional
docs.text:
• Uses official GitHub authentication
  • No copying tokens manually
  • Trusted by GitHub itself

docs.title: 🏗️ Used in Real Projects
docs.text:
GitHub CLI is common in:

  • open-source contributions
  • company workflows
  • CI/CD automation

Learning it early builds real-world habits.

docs.title: Beginner Mental Model
docs.text:
Think of GitHub CLI as:

“GitHub, but typed instead of clicked.”

Same actions — faster execution.

docs.title: One Simple Example
docs.text:
Create a repo and push code:

gh repo create

GitHub is ready in seconds.

docs.title: How Top Engineers Use It
docs.text:
• Create pull requests from terminal
  • Review PRs without opening a browser
  • Manage issues and releases
  • Automate workflows with scripts

Same tool, more power.

docs.title: mise (One Tool to Manage All Tool Versions)
docs.text:
As you learn programming, you’ll notice a common problem:

Different projects need different versions of the same tool.

For example:

  • Project A needs Node.js 18
  • Project B needs Node.js 20
  • Another project needs a different Python version

mise solves this problem.

docs.title: What Is mise?
docs.text:
mise is a tool version manager.

It lets you:

  • install different versions of tools
  • switch versions per project
  • avoid breaking your system setup

All from one place.

docs.title: 🔄 Manage Multiple Versions Easily
docs.text:
Instead of uninstalling and reinstalling tools, mise lets you:

  • keep many versions
  • switch automatically when you enter a project folder

No manual work.

docs.title: 🧠 One Manager for Many Tools
docs.text:
mise can manage:

  • Node.js
  • Python
  • Java
  • Ruby
  • Go
  • and many more

One tool instead of many separate managers.

docs.title: 📁 Project-Based Configuration
docs.text:
Each project can have a file that says:

“Use this version of Node, Python, etc.”

mise reads it automatically.

This prevents:

  • version conflicts
  • broken builds
  • confusion for beginners

docs.title: 🏗️ Used by Professional Engineers
docs.text:
mise is used in:

  • real-world projects
  • teams
  • CI/CD pipelines

It replaces tools like nvm, pyenv, and others with one unified system.

docs.title: Postman (Talk to APIs and See What’s Really Happening)
docs.text:
When you build or use modern software, you often work with APIs.

But APIs are invisible — you can’t “see” them like a website.

Postman lets you see and test APIs clearly.

docs.title: What Is Postman?
docs.text:
Postman is a tool used to send requests to APIs and view the responses.

It helps you:

  • test APIs
  • understand how APIs work
  • debug backend problems
  • learn backend development

All without writing frontend code.

docs.title: 🔍 See API Responses Clearly
docs.text:
Postman shows:

  • returned data
  • status codes
  • errors
  • response time

This makes debugging easy.

docs.title: 🧪 Test Without Writing Code
docs.text:
You can test an API by:

  • entering a URL
  • choosing GET / POST / PUT / DELETE
  • clicking Send

Perfect for beginners.

docs.title: 🧠 Learn How APIs Work
docs.text:
Using Postman teaches:

  • request methods
  • headers
  • JSON data
  • authentication

These are core backend skills.

docs.title: 🤝 Used in Real Projects
docs.text:
Postman is used by:

  • backend developers
  • frontend developers
  • QA engineers
  • DevOps teams

It’s an industry-standard tool.

docs.title: Beginner Mental Model
docs.text:
Think of Postman as:

“A remote control for APIs.”

You press buttons and see how the server responds.

docs.title: Simple Example
docs.text:
Send a request:

  1. Open Postman
  2. Enter an API URL
  3. Select GET
  4. Click Send

You instantly see the response.

docs.title: How Top Engineers Use Postman
docs.text:
• Debug backend issues
  • Test authentication flows
  • Share API collections with teams
  • Verify APIs before deployment

Same tool — deeper usage.

docs.title: Spyder (Python IDE for Learning and Analysis)
docs.text:
When learning Python, writing code in a plain text editor can feel confusing at first.

That’s why many engineers and students use Spyder.

docs.title: What Is Spyder?
docs.text:
Spyder is an IDE (Integrated Development Environment) made specifically for Python.

It combines:

  • a code editor
  • a console
  • variable inspection
  • plots and debugging

All in one window.

docs.title: 🔍 See What Your Code Is Doing
docs.text:
Spyder lets you:

  • view variables in real time
  • inspect data structures
  • see outputs clearly

This is extremely helpful for beginners.

docs.title: 🧠 Perfect for Learning Python
docs.text:
Spyder is popular in:

  • data science
  • scientific computing
  • engineering courses

It makes Python behavior visible, not hidden.

docs.title: 📊 Great for Data & Analysis
docs.text:
Spyder works well with:

  • NumPy
  • Pandas
  • Matplotlib

You can write code and immediately see results.

docs.title: 🐍 Python-Focused (No Distractions)
docs.text:
Unlike general editors, Spyder is:

  • focused only on Python
  • simple to understand
  • learning-oriented

Ideal for students.

docs.title: VS Code (Your Main Coding Workspace)
docs.text:
Most of your time as a developer is spent writing and reading code.

VS Code is where that happens.

docs.title: What Is VS Code?
docs.text:
Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is a code editor.

It helps you:

  • write code
  • read code
  • debug programs
  • manage projects

All in one place.

docs.title: ✍️ Built for Coding
docs.text:
VS Code understands code:

  • syntax highlighting
  • auto-completion
  • error hints

This makes coding faster and less error-prone.

docs.title: 🔌 Powerful Extensions
docs.text:
VS Code can be customized with extensions for:

  • Python
  • Java
  • C / C++
  • Docker
  • GitHub

One editor for many languages.

docs.title: 🧠 Beginner-Friendly, Professional-Ready
docs.text:
• Easy to start
  • Grows with your skills
  • Used by beginners and senior engineers alike

You don’t outgrow it.

docs.title: 🐞 Debugging Made Simple
docs.text:
VS Code includes a visual debugger:

  • set breakpoints
  • step through code
  • inspect variables

This helps you understand how programs work.

docs.title: 🧩 Works Well With Git
docs.text:
VS Code has built-in Git support:

  • see changes
  • commit code
  • resolve conflicts

Perfect for learning version control.

docs.title: Beginner Mental Model
docs.text:
Think of VS Code as:

“A smart notebook that understands programming.”

docs.title: Simple Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open a folder
  2. Write code
  3. Run or debug
  4. Save and commit

Everything stays organized.

docs.title: Ghostty vs Alacritty (Terminal Emulators Explained)
docs.text:
Both Ghostty and Alacritty are terminal emulators. They do the same basic job:

Show the terminal where you run commands.

But they are built with different goals.

docs.title: Alacritty
docs.text: Alacritty is a fast, minimal terminal emulator.

docs.title: Why Engineers Use Alacritty
docs.text:
• Extremely fast
  • Very stable
  • Simple and minimal
  • Great for low-end or older systems

docs.title: How It Feels
docs.text:
• No extra UI
  • Just the terminal
  • You configure everything yourself

docs.title: Best For
docs.text:
• Beginners
  • Students
  • Anyone who wants a reliable terminal

Mental model:

“A clean, fast terminal that just works.”

docs.title: Ghostty
docs.text: Ghostty is a modern, feature-rich terminal.

docs.title: Why Engineers Use Ghostty
docs.text:
• Built-in tabs and splits
  • GPU-accelerated
  • Beautiful default design
  • More features out of the box

docs.title: How It Feels
docs.text:
• More polished
  • More visual
  • Less manual setup needed

docs.title: Best For
docs.text:
• Power users
  • Developers who want advanced features
  • People who live in the terminal all day

Mental model:

“A modern terminal with smart defaults.”

docs.title: Key Differences (Quick Table)
docs.text: Feature Alacritty Ghostty Speed Very fast Very fast Features Minimal Rich Setup Manual config Good defaults UI Simple Polished Beginner-friendly ✅ Yes ⚠️ Slightly advanced

docs.title: Git Alias (Shortcuts for Git Commands)
docs.text:
Git commands can feel long and repetitive, especially for beginners.

Git aliases make Git easier and faster.

docs.title: What Is a Git Alias?
docs.text:
A Git alias is a short name for a longer Git command.

It lets you type less and do more.

Example:

git st

instead of:

git status

Same result. Less typing.

docs.title: ⚡ Speed
docs.text: Small shortcuts save time — and Git is used many times a day.

docs.title: 🧠 Less Mental Load
docs.text:
Short commands are easier to remember.

This helps beginners focus on:

  • understanding Git
  • not memorizing long commands

docs.title: 🔁 Consistent Workflow
docs.text:
Aliases create muscle memory.

Over time, Git becomes natural instead of scary.

docs.title: 🏗️ Used by Professional Engineers
docs.text:
Almost every experienced engineer uses Git aliases.

They are a normal part of real-world workflows.

docs.title: Beginner Mental Model
docs.text:
Think of Git aliases as:

“Nicknames for long Git commands.”

Nothing magical — just shortcuts.

docs.title: Common Beginner Git Aliases
docs.text:
git st    # status
git co    # checkout
git br    # branch
git cm    # commit

These are simple and safe.

docs.title: Where Git Aliases Live
docs.text:
Git aliases are stored in:

  • your Git configuration
  • not inside your project

So they work everywhere.

docs.title: What is MySQL? (Beginner → Pro)
docs.text:
MySQL is a relational database management system (RDBMS). In simple words: it is software used to store, organize, and retrieve data in a structured way.

  • Uses SQL (Structured Query Language)
  • Very fast, reliable, and widely used
  • Open-source (free)
  • Commonly used in web apps, backend systems, and APIs

Popular apps using MySQL: WordPress, Facebook (earlier), YouTube (earlier), e-commerce sites, dashboards.

docs.title: What is a Database?
docs.text:
A database is like a smart Excel sheet but:

  • Handles millions of rows
  • Supports multiple users at once
  • Secure and fast
  • Can be queried using SQL

Example data:

  • Users (id, name, email, password)
  • Orders (order_id, user_id, amount)
  • Products (name, price, stock)

docs.title: What is MySQL Server?
docs.text:
MySQL Server is the actual running service that:

  • Listens for requests
  • Stores data on disk
  • Executes SQL queries
  • Manages users, permissions, backups

Think of it like:

MySQL Server = Engine that runs the database

It usually runs in the background on:

  • localhost
  • Port 3306

docs.title: What is the root User?
docs.text:
• root is the admin (superuser) of MySQL

  • Has full access:

  • Create/delete databases

  • Create users
  • Grant permissions
  • Read/write all data

⚠️ Important:

  • root is powerful
  • Not recommended for production apps

docs.title: What Does user: root and password: root Mean?
docs.text:
This means:

  • Username = root
  • Password = root

Example login:

mysql -u root -p

Then enter:

root

⚠️ This setup is:

  • OK for learning / local development
  • ❌ NOT safe for production

docs.title: Why Is MySQL Used?
docs.text:
Engineers use MySQL because:

  • Easy to learn
  • Extremely stable

  • Works with almost every language:

  • Node.js

  • Java
  • PHP
  • Python
  • C / C++
  • Huge ecosystem & community
  • Excellent performance for structured data

docs.title: How Engineers Use MySQL (Typical Flow)
docs.text:
1. App sends request (login, fetch data)
  2. Backend runs SQL query
  3. MySQL Server returns result
  4. App responds to user

Example SQL:

SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = 'test@example.com';

docs.title: MySQL vs File Storage
docs.text: Feature MySQL Files Speed Fast Slow Search Powerful (SQL) Limited Security Strong Weak Concurrency Multi-user Poor Scaling Easy Hard

docs.title: Beginner → Advanced Path
docs.text:
Beginner

  • SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE
  • Tables & rows
  • Primary keys

Intermediate

  • Indexes
  • Joins
  • Transactions
  • Constraints

Advanced

  • Replication
  • Sharding
  • Performance tuning
  • Backups & recovery

docs.title: MySQL in Real Projects
docs.text:
• Backend APIs
  • Authentication systems
  • Analytics dashboards
  • SaaS products
  • E-commerce platforms

docs.title: Neovim (Edit Code at the Speed of Thought)
docs.text:
Most beginners use a mouse to edit code. Most experienced engineers don’t.

They use Neovim.

docs.title: What Is Neovim?
docs.text:
Neovim is a code editor that runs inside the terminal.

It is a modern, improved version of Vim, designed for:

  • speed
  • efficiency
  • keyboard-only editing

docs.title: ⚡ Extremely Fast
docs.text:
Neovim:

  • starts instantly
  • works smoothly even on large files
  • runs inside the terminal

No waiting. No lag.

docs.title: ⌨️ Keyboard-First Workflow
docs.text:
Neovim is designed so your hands never leave the keyboard.

This:

  • reduces fatigue
  • increases focus
  • makes editing faster over time

docs.title: 🧠 Built for Thinking, Not Clicking
docs.text:
Instead of clicking menus, you:

  • use short commands
  • think in actions (move, change, delete)

This matches how engineers think.

docs.title: 🔌 Highly Customizable
docs.text:
Neovim can be turned into:

  • a full IDE
  • a minimal editor
  • anything in between

Many engineers build their own setup over time.

docs.title: Remote Access & File Transfer (How Engineers Work Across Machines)
docs.text:
As an engineer, you will often work with other computers:

  • servers
  • cloud machines
  • lab systems
  • remote Linux boxes

To do this securely, engineers use SSH and related tools.

docs.title: What Is SSH?
docs.text:
SSH (Secure Shell) is a secure way to connect to another computer over a network.

It lets you:

  • open a remote terminal
  • run commands on another machine
  • manage servers securely

Everything is encrypted.

docs.title: Beginner Mental Model
docs.text:
Think of SSH as:

“A secure remote terminal.”

You type commands on your laptop — they run on another computer.

docs.title: OpenSSH (The Most Common SSH Implementation)
docs.text:
OpenSSH is the most widely used software that provides SSH.

It comes in two main parts:

  • openssh-client
  • openssh-server

docs.title: openssh-client (Connect to Other Computers)
docs.text:
The OpenSSH client is used when you want to connect to another machine.

Example:

ssh user@server_ip

Used for:

  • logging into remote servers
  • accessing cloud machines
  • working on college lab systems

Most systems already have this installed.

docs.title: openssh-server (Allow Others to Connect to You)
docs.text:
The OpenSSH server runs on the machine you want to connect to.

It allows:

  • incoming SSH connections
  • secure remote access

Used on:

  • servers
  • lab machines
  • virtual machines

Without openssh-server, others cannot SSH into that machine.

docs.title: Simple Difference
docs.text: Tool Purpose openssh-client Connect to other machines openssh-server Allow others to connect to you

docs.title: What Is rsync?
docs.text:
rsync is a fast and efficient file transfer tool.

It copies files:

  • locally
  • between computers
  • over SSH

Only changes are transferred, not the entire file.

docs.title: ⚡ Efficient Transfers
docs.text:
• Transfers only modified parts
  • Saves time and bandwidth

docs.title: 🔐 Secure
docs.text:
When used with SSH, rsync is:

  • encrypted
  • safe for remote transfers

docs.title: 🔁 Reliable for Backups
docs.text:
Engineers use rsync for:

  • syncing project folders
  • backups
  • moving large directories

docs.title: Beginner Mental Model
docs.text:
Think of rsync as:

“Smart copy that works locally or remotely.”

docs.title: Simple rsync Example
docs.text:
Copy a folder to a remote server:

rsync -av project/ user@server:/home/user/project/

Only changes are sent.

docs.title: How Engineers Use These Together
docs.text:
Typical workflow:

  1. Use SSH to log into a server
  2. Use rsync to upload or download files
  3. Work remotely as if the machine is local

This is a core Linux skill.

docs.title: Zsh, Oh My Zsh, Powerlevel10k (Beginner → Pro)
What is Zsh?
docs.text:
Zsh (Z Shell) is a command-line shell — the program that reads your commands and runs them.

Think of it as:

The engine behind your terminal

Why engineers love Zsh:

  • Smarter autocomplete
  • Better scripting than bash
  • Globbing (powerful file matching)
  • Plugins & themes
  • Highly customizable

Most modern Linux & macOS setups prefer Zsh over Bash.

docs.title: What is Oh My Zsh?
docs.text:
Oh My Zsh is a framework for managing Zsh configuration.

It does NOT replace Zsh. It enhances it.

What it gives you:

  • Easy plugin system
  • Themes
  • Sensible defaults
  • Huge community

Examples of useful plugins:

  • git → git status, shortcuts
  • z → jump to frequent folders
  • sudo → press Esc + Esc to add sudo
  • autosuggestions → command suggestions
  • syntax-highlighting → red/green command hints

Think:

Zsh = shell Oh My Zsh = power kit for the shell

docs.title: What is Powerlevel10k?
docs.text:
Powerlevel10k (p10k) is a Zsh theme.

But it’s not “just a theme”.

It gives:

  • Extremely fast prompt
  • Git branch + status
  • Exit codes
  • Time, directory, user, host
  • Icons & symbols
  • Fully configurable

Looks like:

➜  ~/project  git:(main ✗)  ❯

Why engineers use it:

  • Instant visual feedback
  • No need to run extra commands
  • Looks professional
  • Saves time

docs.title: btop
docs.text:
btop is a terminal-based system monitor.

Think of it as Task Manager for Linux, but in your terminal.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
btop shows real-time system information in a visual and interactive way:

  • CPU usage (per core)
  • Memory / swap usage
  • Disk usage
  • Network activity
  • Processes running

It uses graphs, bars, and colors to make monitoring easier.

docs.title: Why Developers Use btop
docs.text:
• Quickly spot bottlenecks in CPU, RAM, or network
  • Monitor servers remotely via SSH
  • Identify processes using too many resources
  • Track system performance while running applications

docs.title: fastfetch
docs.text:
fastfetch is a lightweight system information tool for the terminal.

Think of it as Neofetch on steroids—but faster and simpler.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
When you run fastfetch, it shows:

  • OS and version
  • Kernel version
  • Desktop environment / window manager
  • CPU and GPU info
  • Memory usage
  • Shell info
  • Installed packages

All of this is displayed nicely with ASCII logos and colors.

docs.title: Why Developers Use fastfetch
docs.text:
• Quickly see hardware and software info
  • Check system specs for debugging or sharing
  • Verify installations and environments
  • Lightweight, runs instantly in the terminal

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Extremely fast and lightweight
  • Highly configurable: choose what info to show
  • Compatible with Linux, macOS, Windows (WSL)
  • Minimal dependencies
  • Optional ASCII/Unicode logos for fun

docs.title: LazyDocker
docs.text:
LazyDocker is a terminal-based UI for managing Docker containers, images, and volumes.

Think of it as a graphical dashboard for Docker, but inside your terminal.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
LazyDocker allows you to:

  • View running containers
  • Start, stop, restart, or remove containers
  • Check logs for containers in real-time
  • Manage images, networks, and volumes
  • Monitor resource usage (CPU, memory, network) for containers

All of this is interactive, using arrow keys and shortcuts.

docs.title: Why Developers Use LazyDocker
docs.text:
• Makes Docker management easier without memorizing commands
  • Quickly debug container issues
  • View logs and stats in one place
  • Perfect for beginners learning Docker

docs.title: LazyGit
docs.text:
LazyGit is a terminal-based UI for managing Git repositories.

Think of it as a graphical Git dashboard inside your terminal—making Git commands visual and easy to use.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
LazyGit allows you to:

  • View repository status (staged, unstaged, untracked files)
  • Stage, unstage, and commit changes
  • Push and pull branches from remote repositories
  • Checkout branches or tags
  • View logs, diffs, and history
  • Resolve merge conflicts interactively

All using arrow keys, shortcuts, and an intuitive interface.

docs.title: Why Developers Use LazyGit
docs.text:
• Avoid memorizing complex Git commands
  • Quickly manage branches and commits
  • Visualize changes and repository history
  • Perfect for beginners and intermediate developers learning Git

docs.title: exa
docs.text:
exa is a modern replacement for the ls command.

It lists files and directories in a terminal, but in a more readable and visually appealing way.

docs.title: Why Developers Use exa
docs.text:
• Colorized output by file type (folders, executables, etc.)
  • Shows git status if inside a repository
  • Supports icons and tree views
  • More user-friendly than ls, especially for beginners

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
exa
  • Lists files in the current directory.
exa -l
  • Long listing format (like ls -l), shows permissions, owner, size, and date.
exa -la
  • Show all files, including hidden ones (. files).

docs.title: Advanced Usage
docs.text:
Option Description Example -T Tree view exa -T --git Show Git status exa --git -h Human-readable sizes exa -lh -S Sort by size exa -lS -r Reverse order exa -lr

💡 Example: Tree view with Git info

exa -T --git

docs.title: fd
docs.text:
fd is a modern, fast, and user-friendly alternative to find in Linux.

It is used to search for files and directories in your filesystem.

docs.title: Why Developers Use fd
docs.text:
• Faster than find – uses smart defaults and parallelism
  • Simpler syntax – easier for beginners to remember
  • Colorized output – makes results readable
  • Flexible filtering – supports regex, file types, and exclusions

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
fd <pattern>
  • Searches for files/folders matching <pattern> in the current directory and subdirectories.
  • Example: Find all .txt files:
fd .txt

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description Example -t f Search files only fd -t f README -t d Search directories only fd -t d src -e <ext> Match specific extension fd -e md (all Markdown files) -x <cmd> Execute command on each result fd -e log -x rm {} (delete all .log files) -i Ignore case fd -i readme

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Search for a file named config.yaml anywhere:
fd config.yaml
  1. Find all .py files in a project:
fd -e py
  1. Search directories named tests:
fd -t d tests
  1. Delete all .tmp files safely:
fd -e tmp -x rm {}

docs.title: Advanced Usage
docs.text:
• Combine with grep to search inside files:
fd -e txt -x grep "TODO" {}
  • Exclude directories (like .git or node_modules):
fd --exclude .git --exclude node_modules
  • Integrate with scripts for automation or CI/CD pipelines.

docs.title: fzf
docs.text:
fzf stands for Fuzzy Finder.

It is a command-line interactive search tool that lets you find files, directories, or text efficiently using fuzzy matching.

docs.title: Why Developers Use fzf
docs.text:
• Quickly search through large directories or command history
  • Navigate files and Git branches without typing full names
  • Combine with other tools like fd, git, or ripgrep for powerful workflows
  • Saves time compared to manually scrolling or typing long names

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
fzf
  • Opens an interactive search menu for standard input.
  • Example: List files and select one interactively:
ls | fzf
  • Use arrow keys or type a few letters to filter and select a file.

docs.title: File Searching with fzf
docs.text:
Combine fzf with fd:

fd . | fzf
  • fd . lists all files recursively
  • fzf lets you fuzzy search and select

docs.title: Git Integration
docs.text:
git branch | fzf
  • Select a branch interactively to checkout:
git checkout $(git branch | fzf)

docs.title: Command History Search
docs.text:
history | fzf
  • Find a previous command quickly and reuse it.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Fuzzy matching: you don’t need exact names
  • Interactive interface with arrow keys and search
  • Customizable keybindings and actions
  • Works with files, directories, git branches, processes, history

docs.title: ripgrep (rg)
docs.text:
ripgrep, often called rg, is a fast command-line search tool for text inside files.

Think of it as grep on steroids—it searches recursively, is super fast, and respects .gitignore by default.

docs.title: Why Developers Use ripgrep
docs.text:
• Quickly search through codebases for strings or patterns
  • Faster than grep, especially for large projects
  • Respects .gitignore, so you don’t get spam from ignored files
  • Integrates nicely with fzf or other terminal tools for workflow

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
rg "search_term"
  • Searches for "search_term" in current directory and subdirectories
  • Example: Find all occurrences of TODO in a project:
rg TODO

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: Option Description Example -i Ignore case rg -i todo -v Invert match rg -v debug -w Match whole words rg -w function -n Show line numbers rg -n TODO --files List all files (like fd) rg --files -g Include/exclude patterns rg -g '*.py' TODO

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Search for main in Python files only:
rg -g "*.py" main
  1. Search ignoring case:
rg -i "function"
  1. Show line numbers for matches:
rg -n "TODO"
  1. Combine with fzf for interactive search:
rg --files | fzf
  • Search through all project files interactively.

docs.title: Advanced Use
docs.text:
• Preview matches with bat:
rg TODO | fzf --preview 'bat --style=numbers --color=always {}'
  • Use in scripts to automatically find and replace text.
  • Integrates with Neovim/LazyVim for fast in-editor search.

docs.title: zoxide
docs.text:
zoxide is a smarter, faster directory jumper for the terminal.

Think of it as an improved cd command that learns the directories you use most and lets you jump to them instantly.

docs.title: Why Developers Use zoxide
docs.text:
• Save time typing long paths
  • Quickly navigate deeply nested directories
  • Learns your frequently used directories automatically
  • Works with fuzzy matching for partial names
  • Integrates seamlessly with bash, zsh, and fish

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
z <pattern>
  • Jump to a directory matching <pattern>
  • Example: If you often go to /home/user/projects/codekub, you can type:
z codekub

…and zoxide will take you there instantly.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
• Tracks directories you visit using cd
  • Stores them in a database
  • Uses a ranking system to prioritize frequently or recently used paths
  • Supports fuzzy search, so you don’t need exact names

docs.title: Common Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example z <pattern> Jump to matching directory z docs zi <pattern> Jump interactively (select from matches) zi proj z -l <pattern> List matching directories z -l proj zoxide query Show stored directories zoxide query zoxide add <dir> Manually add a directory zoxide add ~/projects

docs.title: Advanced Usage
docs.text:
• Combine with fzf for interactive directory selection:
zoxide query | fzf
  • Integrate into scripts for automation
  • Works with aliases for super-fast navigation:
alias p="z projects"
  • Compatible with terminal multiplexer setups (tmux, Zellij)

docs.title: CodeCompass – Official Website
docs.text:
CodeCompass is the official hub for everything related to the Codekub learning ecosystem.

It brings together:

  • Beginner guides
  • Tool explanations
  • Learning resources
  • Developer workflows

CodeCompass helps students understand not just what to install, but why they are using it.

docs.title: CSE Starter Kit
docs.text:
The CSE Starter Kit is a beginner-focused section of CodeCompass.

It is designed for:

  • First-year CSE / IT students
  • Programming beginners
  • Students new to Linux and developer tools

What it contains:

  • Step-by-step beginner guides
  • Clear explanations of tools (Git, Docker, Neovim, VS Code, etc.)
  • Learning paths for programming and system tools
  • No assumptions of prior knowledge

Think of it as:

“Everything a CSE student wishes they had on day one.”

docs.title: DevSetup
docs.text:
DevSetup is a practical tools page.

It provides:

  • Ready-to-use terminal commands
  • One-line installers
  • Setup instructions for development tools

Purpose:

  • Save time
  • Avoid setup mistakes
  • Ensure consistent environments

Instead of searching random blogs, you get tested, copy-paste-safe commands.

docs.title: Repeto
docs.text:
Repeto focuses on real-world experience and opportunities.

It covers:

  • Internships
  • Research opportunities
  • Hackathons
  • Repeated practice & application learning

Why it exists:

  • Beginners often learn tools but don’t know where to apply them
  • Repetro bridges the gap between learning and experience

docs.title: WhatsApp Web
docs.text:
WhatsApp Web is the browser version of WhatsApp.

  • Lets you chat from your laptop instead of your phone
  • Useful for quick communication without switching devices

docs.title: Why Developers Use It
docs.text:
• Discuss ideas with teammates
  • Ask quick questions without leaving the code
  • Share links, screenshots, and notes fast

Mental model:

“WhatsApp on your computer.”

docs.title: LocalSend
docs.text:
LocalSend is a tool for fast file sharing on the local network.

  • Works without the internet
  • Transfer files between your laptop, phone, or PC
  • Very fast and secure

docs.title: Why Developers Use It
docs.text:
• Quickly share project files or builds with a colleague in the same network
  • Avoid cloud upload/download
  • Safe for confidential work

Mental model:

“AirDrop for Linux/PC users.”

docs.title: Slack
docs.text:
Slack is a team communication and collaboration tool.

  • Organized into channels (topics, projects, or teams)
  • Supports messages, files, video calls, and integrations

docs.title: Why Developers Use It
docs.text:
• Keep communication organized
  • Integrates with GitHub, Jira, CI/CD pipelines, and notifications
  • Share updates, ask questions, and track project progress

Mental model:

“Professional chat app for work projects.”

docs.title: Discord
docs.text:
Discord is a community and team communication platform.

  • Supports text, voice, and video chat
  • Popular for dev communities and open-source projects
  • Channels can be public or private

docs.title: Why Developers Use It
docs.text:
• Connect with other developers or communities
  • Ask for help or discuss programming topics
  • Real-time collaboration during hackathons or coding sessions

Mental model:

“Slack, but more community-oriented and casual.”

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Tool Main Use Developer Benefit WhatsApp Web Quick chat Fast informal communication LocalSend Local file transfer Share project files fast Slack Team collaboration Organized work communication Discord Community & team chat Real-time discussions, communities

docs.title: Exercism
docs.text:
Exercism is a practice platform for coding exercises.

  • Provides exercises in many programming languages
  • Gives feedback and mentorship from the community
  • Focuses on learning by doing

Why developers use it:

  • Improve coding skills
  • Learn new languages
  • Practice problem-solving regularly

docs.title: freeCodeCamp
docs.text:
freeCodeCamp is a free platform to learn web development and programming.

  • Offers interactive tutorials and projects
  • Covers HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, Data Science
  • Includes certifications after completing projects

Why developers use it:

  • Start web development from scratch
  • Build a portfolio with projects
  • Learn practical skills for jobs

docs.title: The Missing Semester
docs.text:
The Missing Semester is a free course by MIT about practical computer science tools.

  • Teaches Linux, Git, shell, debugging, editors, and scripting
  • Focuses on skills often skipped in CS courses

Why developers use it:

  • Become efficient on Linux and terminals
  • Learn tools professional engineers use
  • Fill knowledge gaps not taught in traditional courses

docs.title: MIT OpenCourseWare (MIT OCW)
docs.text:
MIT OCW offers free lecture notes, videos, and assignments from MIT courses.

  • Covers Computer Science, Engineering, Math, and more
  • Self-paced, open access

Why developers use it:

  • Learn from world-class university materials
  • Follow a structured CS curriculum for self-study
  • Deep understanding of algorithms, systems, AI, etc.

docs.title: Odin Project
docs.text:
The Odin Project is a free full-stack web development curriculum.

  • Covers HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Node.js, databases
  • Focuses on building projects and portfolio
  • Open-source and community-driven

Why developers use it:

  • Learn web development from scratch
  • Gain project-based learning experience
  • Get ready for internships or junior developer jobs

docs.title: OSSU (Open Source Society University)
docs.text:
OSSU provides a free self-taught CS degree using online resources.

  • Curated path of MIT, Harvard, and other online courses
  • Covers CS fundamentals, algorithms, OS, networking, AI
  • Community-driven study groups

Why developers use it:

  • Get a full CS education for free
  • Follow a structured path like a university degree
  • Build strong foundation before job hunting

docs.title: Rayyana Coding School
docs.text:
Rayyana Coding School is a beginner-friendly coding education platform.

  • Offers guides, tutorials, and project-based learning
  • Covers programming, web, and practical tools

Why developers use it:

  • Simplified learning for beginners
  • Step-by-step guidance on real-world tools
  • Community support and exercises

docs.title: Substack
docs.text:
Substack is a platform to read and write newsletters.

  • Many developers share programming tutorials, tips, and industry news
  • You can follow experts and stay updated

Why developers use it:

  • Learn from experienced developers
  • Stay updated on trends, tools, and best practices
  • Get regular curated learning content

docs.title: Quick Summary Table
docs.text: Platform Focus Developer Benefit Exercism Coding exercises Practice, mentorship, problem-solving freeCodeCamp Web development Learn from scratch, build portfolio Missing Semester CS tools Terminal, Linux, Git, productivity MIT OCW University courses Structured learning, deep CS knowledge Odin Project Full-stack web Project-based learning, portfolio OSSU Self-taught CS degree Structured free CS curriculum Rayyana Coding School Beginner coding Step-by-step practical learning Substack Newsletters Stay updated, read expert insights

docs.title: CodeCombat
docs.text:
Website: https://codecombat.com/ What it is: A dungeon adventure game where you write real code to move your hero, defeat enemies, and solve challenges. Why use it:

  • Learn programming logic and syntax while playing
  • Covers Python, JavaScript, and more
  • Fun way to get started with coding

docs.title: Battle Snake
docs.text:
Website: https://play.battlesnake.com/ What it is: Multiplayer game where you program your snake to compete with others in an arena. Why use it:

  • Practice algorithms and AI logic
  • Learn real-time decision making
  • Introduces competitive programming in a fun environment

docs.title: CodinGame
docs.text:
Website: https://www.codingame.com/home What it is: Platform with coding puzzles, multiplayer games, and competitions. Why use it:

  • Practice problem-solving and algorithms
  • Supports many programming languages
  • Gamified learning makes practice enjoyable

docs.title: Robocode
docs.text:
Website: https://robocode.sourceforge.io/ What it is: Program virtual robots to fight in an arena using Java or .NET. Why use it:

  • Learn OOP and strategy programming
  • Hands-on coding for AI and automation
  • Teaches debugging and iterative improvement

docs.title: Screeps
docs.text:
Website: https://screeps.com/a/#!/sim What it is: MMO strategy game where you write JavaScript AI to control units in a persistent world. Why use it:

  • Learn JavaScript in a realistic programming environment
  • Focus on automation, AI, and efficiency
  • Real-world programming concepts in a game

docs.title: Knight Lab Mystery
docs.text:
Website: https://mystery.knightlab.com/ What it is: SQL-based puzzle game to solve mysteries. Why use it:

  • Practice SQL queries in a fun narrative
  • Learn database logic through problem-solving
  • Engaging for beginners and intermediate learners

docs.title: SQL Noir
docs.text:
Website: https://www.sqlnoir.com/ What it is: Learn SQL by solving detective cases. Why use it:

  • Interactive way to understand database queries
  • Improves logical thinking
  • Gamified learning of real-world SQL

docs.title: CheckiO
docs.text:
Website: https://checkio.org/ What it is: Coding challenge platform with fun games and missions. Why use it:

  • Solve algorithmic puzzles
  • Improve Python or TypeScript skills
  • Learn through interactive challenges

docs.title: CSS Grid Garden
docs.text:
Website: https://cssgridgarden.com/ What it is: Game that teaches CSS Grid by watering plants. Why use it:

  • Practice layout design in CSS
  • Visual and interactive learning
  • Great for front-end beginners

docs.title: Elevator Saga
docs.text:
Website: http://play.elevatorsaga.com/ What it is: Programming game to control elevators efficiently. Why use it:

  • Learn JavaScript logic
  • Practice optimization and algorithms
  • Fun way to understand event-driven programming

docs.title: Flexbox Defense
docs.text:
Website: http://www.flexboxdefense.com/ What it is: Learn CSS Flexbox by defending your base against attackers. Why use it:

  • Interactive CSS learning
  • Reinforces Flexbox properties through gameplay
  • Fun front-end skill-building

docs.title: Flexbox Froggy
docs.text:
Website: https://flexboxfroggy.com/ What it is: Guide frogs to lilypads using CSS Flexbox commands. Why use it:

  • Beginner-friendly CSS practice
  • Visual, interactive, and fun
  • Helps solidify layout concepts

docs.title: Awesome Low Level Design
docs.text:
Website: https://github.com/ashishps1/awesome-low-level-design What it is: A curated list of resources to master Low-Level Design (LLD) concepts for software engineering interviews. Why use it:

  • Learn design patterns and OOP principles
  • Prepare for system design questions in interviews
  • Build strong foundation for writing clean, maintainable code

docs.title: IndiaBIX
docs.text:
Website: https://www.indiabix.com/ What it is: Platform with aptitude, reasoning, and technical questions. Why use it:

  • Practice logical reasoning and quantitative aptitude
  • Prepare for coding, placement, and competitive exams
  • Improve problem-solving speed

docs.title: Interview Guide
docs.text:
Website: https://interviewguide.dev/technical-knowledge What it is: A collection of technical knowledge and interview tips for software engineers. Why use it:

  • Quick reference for important topics in interviews
  • Covers both coding and system design basics
  • Helps organize preparation efficiently

docs.title: LeetCode
docs.text:
Website: https://leetcode.com/ What it is: Platform to learn algorithms and data structures through coding challenges. Why use it:

  • Solve real interview-style problems
  • Practice DSA for coding interviews
  • Track progress and compete with others
  • Supports multiple programming languages

docs.title: Pramp
docs.text:
Website: https://www.pramp.com/#/ What it is: Platform to practice coding interviews with peers. Why use it:

  • Real interview simulations
  • Receive live feedback
  • Improve communication and problem-solving skills

docs.title: GeeksforGeeks Puzzles
docs.text:
Website: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/category/puzzles/ What it is: Collection of programming and logical puzzles. Why use it:

  • Sharpen logical and algorithmic thinking
  • Prepare for tricky interview questions
  • Practice consistently to improve speed

docs.title: System Design Primer
docs.text:
Website: https://github.com/donnemartin/system-design-primer What it is: Resource to learn how to design large-scale systems. Why use it:

  • Prepare for system design interviews
  • Learn scalable architecture, caching, databases, and APIs
  • Understand real-world software design patterns

docs.title: Take U Forward
docs.text:
Website: https://takeuforward.org/ What it is: Platform for DSA and interview preparation. Why use it:

  • Step-by-step guidance for coding problems
  • Covers arrays, trees, graphs, dynamic programming, and more
  • Ideal for beginners and intermediate learners

docs.title: Tech Interview Handbook
docs.text:
Website: https://www.techinterviewhandbook.org/ What it is: Complete guide for technical interview preparation. Why use it:

  • Covers resume tips, system design, coding interviews, behavioral interviews
  • Helps organize your preparation
  • One-stop guide for beginners aiming for top tech companies
